comments:
Using wtp-1.0RC1
I am trying to use 'IBM WebSphere v6.0' as a new server runtime, and then use it as the target runtime for a Connector project, or a Utility project.  When I press finish on the 'Connector Import' wizard, nothing happens in the wizard at all (I can press finish forever - well something is happening see below).  When I try to define 'IBM WebSphere v6.0' as the 'Target runtime' in the 'Utility Module' wizard, I get an error message 'Invalid target server selected', after pressing 'finish' in the 'New Server Runtime' wizard.

If I look in the .log file after trying to do the rar import, there are only 2 messages:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core 4 0 2005-12-02 15:48:25.411
!MESSAGE Runtime component type was.base has not been defined. It is used in plugin com.ibm.etools.portlet.facets.

!MESSAGE Runtime component type was.base has not been defined. It is used in plugin com.ibm.etools.portlet.facets.

One more thing which is not working (although it may once the above is corrected), is that only j2ee.jar, and not all the jars in the 'lib' directory of the WebSphere installation, is the only jar file added to the build path of the server runtime container.  I would expect all the jar files to be there.  We have code which programmatically sets the the runtime container on the project, and I only get j2ee.jar on the classpath.

The import of connector has been fixed for RC2.
For the utility project creation please follow 116495
Added to Hit List at the request of Harold Gartner. I've increased the priority to P2 in case you reopen.

This bug is not entirely fixed in RC2.  In the original text:

"One more thing which is not working (although it may once the above is
corrected), is that only j2ee.jar, and not all the jars in the 'lib' directory
of the WebSphere installation, is the only jar file added to the build path of
the server runtime container.  I would expect all the jar files to be there."

All of the jar file in the lib directory need to be set on the container's classpath.  Otherwise the code we generate won't compile as is references classes outside of j2ee.jar.  Creating a basic J2EE runtime library adds all of the jars in the specified directory to the container classpath.  I would assume that targetting a Webshpere server should be doing exactly the same thing.
Tim, on the RC4 call today, I believe you said you would close this.

Discussed on today's WTP 1.0 shutdown call. Since the original blocking bug has been fixed and we do not plan to fix the remaining problem in 1.0, it is being deferred. The workaround for now is to manually add the required jars to the classpath.
Sinan, can you fix this in 1.0.1? Thx.
Sinan can you report on the status of this bug.  Is it fixed?
